newsitem.title: CHINA: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS-Hutchinson deal may spur others.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS-Hutchinson deal may spur others.

text.p: The stunning success of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd's US$2.0 billion global bond may inspire further U.S. dollar issues from China and Hong Kong, bankers said on Friday.
Hutchison Whampoa Ltd launched its US$2.0 billion four-tranche issue overnight in New York, increased from US$1 billion, attracting a total US$7 billion in bids.
Spreads on Hutchison's global came in on Friday by an average two to four basis points after buying from investors who missed out on the offering on Thursday.
Other potential issuers from greater China included Sun Hung Kai Properties Co Ltd and CITIC Pacific Ltd, bankers said.
"People have been extremely bullish on Hong Kong and China," the vice president of a U.S. investment bank said.
"Hong Kong companies'... activity in the yankee market has reached a new level of maturity," he said.
Bankers said U.S. investors watching Hong Kong, particularly property companies, had seen "continuing spectacular results including massive cash flows, disciplined management.
"All the things that were promised three or four years ago have come true," one banker said.
"People are believers in China," a syndicate member at an Asian institution said.
"I think China is on the beginning of a (winning) streak...we're doing everything we can out of China," he said.
In other news, bankers said the mandate for Hua Nan Commercial Bank's US$150 million floating-rate note may have gone to Bayerische Landesbank and Tokyo-Mitsubishi.
Moody's Investors Service rates the Taiwanese bank A2, and all-in pricing will be in the low 20s for a five-year issue with put and call options at year three, bankers said.
June Labuan Ltd launched a US$105 million five-year floating-rate note (FRN) through Nomura (Singapore) Ltd.
The FRNs were issued at par to float at a margin of 90 basis points over the six-month London Interbank Offered Rate.
In Shanghai, Asia-Pacific central bankers warned that excessive volatility in currency markets could affect maintenance of monetary and financial among member economies.

"Governors recognised the importance of stability of foreign exchange markets, which should reflect fundamentals and in this regard, the governors commended the significant adjustment made by the region's economies," they said in a statement.
The statement also warned that asset price bubbles could have a significant impact on economic activity, the health of the financial system and inflation.
Central bankers from China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea and Thailand attended the meeting.
Their meeting followed weeks of speculative attacks on some Asian currencies, particularly the Thai baht, which has fallen about 20 percent since its flotation on July 2.
